content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

This thumbnail shows multiple sections of tissue, including several (approximately 7) well-circumscribed, basophilic nodules embedded in paler fibro-adipose tissue. These nodules are consistent in appearance with lymph nodes of varying sizes. My initial task is to systematically examine each of these lymph nodes for the presence of metastatic tumor.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am starting my systematic evaluation of the lymph nodes. The zoomed-in area corresponds to the periphery of the uppermost lymph node. I specifically chose this region because metastatic tumor cells typically first arrive and deposit in the subcapsular sinus, which is located just beneath the lymph node capsule. Examining this area is the highest yield location for detecting early metastatic disease. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The green box is placed over one of the largest lymph nodes, located in the lower-left portion of the tissue cluster. When screening for metastasis, pathologists systematically examine each lymph node. Larger nodes are often prioritized for initial examination as size can be an indicator of involvement, although it can also be due to reactive changes. I am zooming in to assess the architecture and cellular composition of this node to determine if it is benign/reactive or contains metastatic tumor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. A pathologist must examine every lymph node thoroughly. The zoomed-in area is located at the periphery of one of the lower lymph nodes (the fourth one from the top). This specific location, just under the capsule, is the subcapsular sinus. The subcapsular sinus is the first place tumor cells typically deposit when they travel to a lymph node via lymphatic drainage. Therefore, this is a critical and high-yield area to scrutinize for early metastatic disease. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist evaluating a colorectal cancer case, the primary task for lymph nodes is to identify any metastasis. I would systematically examine every lymph node on the slide. The green box is positioned on one of the larger lymph nodes in the bottom right quadrant. This specific node is selected for detailed examination to assess its architecture and cytology for any evidence of tumor cells, which would make it a 'positive' lymph node and be crucial for staging the cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the primary task for this specimen is to identify any lymph node metastasis. Therefore, I must systematically examine every lymph node on the slide. The green box is placed on one of the smaller lymph nodes in the lower right quadrant. I am zooming into this specific node as part of my routine, comprehensive evaluation to search for metastatic tumor cells, which might be present as small clusters or individual cells and require high magnification to detect. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the protocol for staging colorectal cancer requires examining every lymph node submitted. The green box highlights one of the lymph node clusters, specifically the one located in the upper-central portion of the tissue section, just superior to the largest lymph node at the bottom. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic, methodical examination of all lymph nodes on the slide to search for any evidence of metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I can clearly see the lymph node capsule (top) and the underlying subcapsular sinus and lymphoid cortex. Within the subcapsular sinus, there are clusters of atypical, non-lymphoid cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding small, dark lymphocytes. They have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, enlarged and irregular nuclei, and are forming cohesive groups. These features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The high-magnification view reveals a complete effacement of the normal lymph node architecture (i.e., no distinct follicles, sinuses, or paracortex). The node is replaced by a dense, diffuse, and monotonous population of small, dark (hyperchromatic) lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. There are no features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as gland formation, nests of large atypical epithelial cells, or significant necrosis. The morphology is highly suggestive of a lymphoproliferative disorder, such as small lymphocytic lymphoma/chronic lymphocytic leukemia (SLL/CLL). Therefore, this is a pathologically involved lymph node, but the involvement appears to be by a lymphoma, which would be a separate, concurrent diagnosis, rather than metastasis from the colorectal cancer.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The high-magnification view shows the edge of the lymph node. The majority of the field is composed of a dense population of small, round, dark-staining lymphocytes, which are the normal cells of the lymph node. However, infiltrating the subcapsular sinus and the underlying cortex, there are clusters and nests of atypical cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and enlarged, irregular nuclei with vesicular chromatin. These features are characteristic of malignant epithelial cells. My impression is that this is metastatic adenocarcinoma in a lymph node. This node is positive for metastasis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a portion of the lymph node. There is a clear demarcation between two different cell populations. On the upper right, there is a dense population of small, dark lymphocytes, which is part of the normal lymphoid tissue. However, infiltrating from the lower left, there are clusters and nests of large, atypical epithelial cells. These cells have abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, large pleomorphic nuclei with irregular nuclear contours, and prominent nucleoli. They are arranged in poorly-formed glandular structures. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma, which has replaced a significant portion of the normal lymphoid parenchyma.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a section of a lymph node characterized by a dense population of lymphocytes with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. The lymphoid tissue is enclosed by a thin fibrous capsule, with perinodal fat visible at the right and bottom edges. There are no obvious atypical glandular structures or clusters of malignant cells to suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. Some processing artifact (smudging) is present in the center. My impression of this specific field is that of a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy. The entire lymph node must be scrutinized to make a definitive diagnosis.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see the architecture of a lymph node. There are multiple, well-defined lymphoid follicles, each with a pale-staining germinal center and a darker surrounding mantle zone. The interfollicular areas are composed of a mixed population of small lymphocytes and other immune cells. Crucially, I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, mucin pools, or tumor cell nests that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node showing follicular hyperplasia, with no evidence of malignancy (negative for metastasis).
